I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  the  participating 
developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to promote the life 
cycle management of fluorocarbons.1 The life cycle management of fluorocarbons requires (i) 
developing, manufacturing, and using climate-friendly refrigerants with zero or low global warming 
potential (GWP) as an alternative to fluorocarbons with high GWP, which includes replacing old 
cooling  equipment  (upstream);  and  (ii)  recovering,  recycling,  and  destroying  the  discarded 
fluorocarbons  (midstream  and  downstream).  The  replacement  of  old  equipment  with  new 
technologies also leads to energy efficiency and fewer carbon dioxide (CO ) emissions from 
2
energy sources by reducing the use of electricity generated through the combustion of fossil fuels. 
ADB's technical and capacity-building support will focus on the energy efficiency measures 
associated with the life cycle management of fluorocarbons. 
 
2.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  priorities  relating  to  climate  change  and  disaster  risk 
management of ADB's Work Program and Budget Framework, 2021–2023 and is included in the 
2021 ADB Management-approved results-based work plan of the Sustainable Development and 
Climate Change Department (SDCC). The TA is one of the concrete actions taken by ADB as a 
signatory of the Initiative on Fluorocarbons Life Cycle Management (IFL), which Japan's Ministry 
of the Environment initiated in December 2019 at the 25th session of the Conference of Parties 
to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.2 
 
3.  The TA will be a part of ADB’s Carbon Market Program (CMP). Established in 2006, the 
CMP is one of the flagship climate change initiatives of ADB; it provides technical support and 
carbon finance to greenhouse gas mitigation projects in DMCs.3 The TA will be a part of the CMP’s 
Technical Support Facility, one of the main instruments through which ADB assists its DMCs in 
taking more mitigation actions through carbon markets. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  It is estimated that 3.6 billion cooling appliances are in use globally for space cooling, 
stationary refrigeration, and mobile cooling; and that up to 14 billion cooling appliances would be 
required by 2050 if cooling were to be provided to all those who need it.4 The growing demand 
for cooling equipment will increase global warming effects because of the emissions from 
hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and other old refrigerants used in such equipment, and from CO  
2
emissions  where  the  appliances  rely  on  electricity  from  fossil  fuel-based  energy  sources. 
Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are commonly used as 
refrigerants in cooling equipment and in aerosols and are very potent greenhouse gases.5 HCFCs 
and CFCs are ozone-depleting substances that are very harmful to the environment if released 
into the air through leakage or improper disposal of cooling equipment. Recognizing the impact 
 
1  Fluorocarbons: any of various chemically inert compounds containing carbon and fluorine used chiefly as lubricants, 
refrigerants, and nonstick coatings. 
2  The TA is aligned with one of the key items of the joint work program (2020–2022) that ADB has agreed with Japan's 
Ministry of the Environment under the Letter of Intent on Cooperation for Environment between the two sides. The 
TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 February 2021. 
3  The CMP currently includes the (i) Future Carbon Fund, (ii) Technical Support Facility, (iii) Japan Fund for the Joint 
Crediting Mechanism, and (iv) Article 6 Support Facility. New funds and facilities for the CMP are being developed. 
4  United Nations Environment Programme and International Energy Agency. 2020. Cooling Emissions and Policy 
Synthesis Report: Benefits of cooling efficiency and the Kigali Amendment. Nairobi and Paris. 
5  HCFCs and CFCs have high GWP values relative to CO2—ranging from 79 to 1,980 for HCFCs and from 4,660 to 
13,900 for CFCs—for the 100-year time horizon. Source: Greenhouse Gas Protocol. Global Warming Protocol 
Values.

2 
of HCFCs, CFCs, and other substances on the ozone layer, countries came together in 1987 to 
finalize the Montreal Protocol, an international agreement to phase out the production of these 
substances. As an alternative to HFCFs and CFCs, HFCs were developed as new refrigerants 
for cooling equipment. However, HFCs are also greenhouse gases with a very high GWP value 
of 4 to 12,400 relative to CO for the 100-year time horizon (GWP Values, footnote 5). The use of 
2 
HFCs has increased rapidly as global demand for air conditioners and refrigerators continues to 
grow. Global HFC emissions are increasing by 10%–15% annually and are expected to reach 
between 5.5 gigatons and 8.8 gigatons of CO  equivalent (CO e) per year by 2050, which is 
2 2
equivalent to 9%–19% (CO e basis) of projected global CO  emissions in 2050 in a business-as-
2 2
usual scenario.6 Recognizing this, countries adopted the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal 
Protocol in 2016, agreeing to gradually reduce the use of HFCs by more than 80% by 2047. 
 
5.  Despite the international commitments in place, it is estimated that global cumulative 
emissions of fluorocarbons from 2020 to 2060 are likely to be 63–69 gigatons of CO e. Some 
2
DMCs have no laws or policies to curtail HFC emissions. Even among the countries that do, only 
a few have systems in place to enforce, or at least provide incentives for, the proper management 
of fluorocarbons. Therefore, it is critical to promote the life cycle management of fluorocarbons 
and the associated energy efficiency improvements in the cooling industry (e.g., space cooling, 
stationary refrigeration, and mobile cooling) to meet the obligations under the Montreal Protocol 
and its amendments, as well as the Paris Agreement goals. 
 
6.  Contributions  to  the  Sustainable  Development  Goals  and  ADB’s  operational 
priorities under Strategy 2030. The TA will directly contribute to Sustainable Development Goal 
(SDG) 13 (climate action) and ADB’s operational priority 3 by helping DMCs promote or even 
enforce fluorocarbon life cycle management and energy efficiency in the cooling industry. In 
addition, the TA will contribute to SDG 5 (gender equality) and ADB’s operational priority 2 by 
ensuring women’s full participation in capacity-building and awareness-raising opportunities 
under the TA. The TA will indirectly contribute to SDG 9 (industry, innovation, and infrastructure) 
by preparing investment projects to develop the infrastructure for the life cycle management of 
fluorocarbons and help the cooling industry to be energy efficient and sustainable. 
 
7.  Cooling systems are indispensable for human health in hot climates, and for storing and 
transporting food and medical supplies, which has become more evident during the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic. To ensure the sustainability of cooling systems, it is critical to 
promote proper fluorocarbon life cycle management and energy efficiency. Improvements in the 
practices of the cooling industry will also boost the capacity and resilience of participating DMCs 
to respond to COVID-19 and any similar shocks in the future. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: use of zero or low GWP refrigerants in the 
cooling industry increased in participating DMCs, and use of energy-efficient cooling technologies 
increased in participating DMCs.7 The TA will have the following outcome: DMCs’ actions to 
promote the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated energy efficiency in the 
 
6  G. J. M. Velders et al. 2009. The large contribution of projected HFC emissions to future climate forcing. Proceedings 
of the National Academy of Sciences Jul 2009. 106 (27) 10949-10954. 
7  Defined by the TA.

3 
cooling industry increased.8 The outcome indicator will be that by 2023, (i) the recommendations 
on the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated energy efficiency gains in the 
cooling industry are incorporated into national plans, policies, and/or laws in at least one DMC; 
and (ii) at least one new investment and/or a project component dedicated to the life cycle 
management of fluorocarbons and associated energy efficiency measures in the cooling industry 
is included in the ADB pipeline. The target fluorocarbons are HCFCs, CFCs, and HFCs. Since 
their life cycle management includes the collection, treatment, and disposal or destruction of 
obsolete and inefficient cooling equipment, the TA will also contribute to better solid waste 
management (i.e., handling of used cooling appliances) in each of the participating DMCs. The 
TA will focus on DMCs that have joined the IFL (para. 2), such as Maldives, Mongolia, the 
Philippines, and Viet Nam; or are considering to join it and have economies of a size and structure 
that promise high demand for this TA support and high potential impact, such as Indonesia and 
Thailand. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Developing  member  countries’  knowledge  and  awareness  of,  and 
capacity for the life cycle management of fluorocarbons increased. The TA team will identify 
and assess the current policies, laws, and regulations in participating DMCs with reference to 
global good practices, including through desktop analysis and consultation with relevant entities 
from the public and private sectors. The team will prepare a gap analysis to assess the current 
state of the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and the associated energy consumption in 
each participating DMCs. The analysis will inform the recommendations to be developed under 
output 3. The team will also disseminate the knowledge gained under the TA to a wider range of 
stakeholders in the Asia and Pacific region through workshops and a knowledge product. The 
increased knowledge, awareness, and capacity of the stakeholders in the participating DMCs will 
be the basis for achieving the outcome. 
 
10.  Output 2: Options for advanced technologies and innovative solutions suitable for 
developing member countries’ local practices related to the life cycle management of 
fluorocarbons  identified.  The  TA  team  will  study  the  options  for  introducing  advanced 
technologies, other innovative solutions, and available business models that would foster the 
uptake of fluorocarbon life cycle management and associated energy efficiency improvements by 
the cooling industry in each participating DMC. The study will inform the recommendations to be 
developed under output 3. 
 
11.  Output 3: Recommendations for the developing member countries to promote the 
life cycle management of fluorocarbons prepared. Based on the assessments under outputs 1 
and 2, the TA team will first develop a series of options broadly applicable to DMCs to promote 
the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated energy efficiency in the cooling 
industry. Users of cooling equipment, both in the public and private sectors, will be closely 
consulted throughout the preparation of the recommendations. Based on the options, the team 
will tailor its recommendations to the participating DMCs, which they can use for national action 
plans, policy reforms, amendments to laws and/or regulations, and investment opportunities 
depending on the local context. The TA team will explore and recommend the possible use of 
carbon market mechanisms under the Paris Agreement, such as the Joint Crediting Mechanism, 
to encourage investments in the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated energy 
efficiency improvements by the cooling industry. Assuming that the participating DMCs are able 
to sustain their commitment to the Montreal Protocol and its Kigali Amendment, and to the Paris 
 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
Agreement, it is highly likely that the outcome will be achieved if the participating DMCs will 
favorably receive the recommendations prepared under output 3 and apply these in their national 
plans, policies, and/or laws. 
 
12.  The TA is innovative because it aims to develop recommendations for participating DMCs 
to incorporate the new concept of life cycle management of fluorocarbons into their national laws, 
regulations, and/or policies. These recommendations may also serve as the basis for developing 
new projects to support the life cycle management of fluorocarbons with innovative technologies 
and business models, which could transform the greenhouse gas emission profile of the cooling 
industry in the participating DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the Asian 
Clean  Energy  Fund  (ACEF)9 under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility,  and 
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
14.  The use of ACEF for the TA will follow the implementation guidelines of ACEF, including 
the list of ineligible expenditure items, such as: (i) purchases of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil 
servants, (iii) scholarships or internships, and (iv) civil works and other related expenses. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. SDCC will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; 
organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. The Climate 
Change and Disaster Risk Management Division of SDCC will lead the overall implementation 
and coordinate closely with the relevant sector and thematic groups under SDCC and ADB’s 
operations  departments.10 International  and  national  consultants  will  be  recruited  through 
individual consultant selection.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility for Promoting Life Cycle Management of Fluorocarbons, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  DMCs’ knowledge and awareness of, and capacity for the life cycle management of 
fluorocarbons increased 
1.1 Conduct a gap analysis of current life cycle management of fluorocarbons, including the status of 
inclusion of fluorocarbons in the national greenhouse gas inventory, and associated energy 
consumption in the cooling industry of the participating DMCs (Q2–Q4 2021). 
1.2 Agree on the scope and form of seminars and workshops, including the designation of roles and 
responsibilities (Q2 2021–Q1 2022). 
1.3 Conduct seminars or workshops for each of the participating DMCs to disseminate and discuss the 
above results (Q1 2022–Q2 2023). 
1.4 Develop a knowledge product on the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated energy 
efficiency in the cooling industry based on outputs 1–3 (Q1 2022–Q2 2023). 
1.5 Disseminate results of the TA activities and lessons in international seminars or workshops to be 
organized by the Initiative on Fluorocarbons Life Cycle Management (Q2 2021–Q2 2023). 
 
2.  Options for advanced technologies and innovative solutions suitable for DMCs’ local 
practices related to the life cycle management of fluorocarbons identified 
2.1 Study the options for advanced technologies and other innovative solutions available in the market 
(Q2–Q4 2021). 
2.2 Review good practices in business models for the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and 
associated energy efficiency measures in the cooling industry (Q2–Q4 2021). 
2.3 Identify possible application of technologies, solutions, and business models identified under 2.1 and 
2.2 in the local context of each participating DMC (Q3 2021–Q1 2023). 
 
3.  Recommendations for the DMCs to promote the life cycle management of fluorocarbons 
prepared 
3.1 Prepare recommendations to promote the life cycle management of fluorocarbons and associated 
energy efficiency in the cooling industry based on the gap analysis and the options for advanced 
technology and innovative solutions (Q1 2022–Q2 2023). 
3.2 Promote the development of a fluorocarbon inventory, if not yet available in the DMCs, including the 
recording of hydrofluorocarbon emission reductions in the national greenhouse gas inventory of 
each participating DMC (Q3 2021–Q1 2023). 
3.3 Assist the DMCs in developing a target to reduce hydrofluorocarbon emissions that will be reflected 
in their nationally determined contributions where the inventory is available, or developed during the 
TA period (Q3 2021–Q1 2023). 
3.4 Identify opportunities for ADB’s investment from upstream to downstream in close cooperation with 
ADB’s operations departments, with associated investment costs (Q1 2022–Q2 2023). 
 
TA Management Activities 
Mobilize international and national consultants (Q2 2021–Q1 2022). 
Prepare semiannual TA progress report (Q4 2021, Q2 2022, and Q4 2022). 
Prepare TA completion report (Q2 2023).
